description.narrative: Households and communities, including those in humanitarian situations, have increased capacity to adopt behaviours conducive to improving WASH practices.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Households and communities, including those in humanitarian situations, have increased capacity to adopt behaviours conducive to improving WASH practices.

description.narrative: In 2019, UNICEF supported the government to develop an acceleration plan to end open defecation and the training materials on the municipality wide ODF approach, water safety planning, menstrual hygiene management and the three stars approach, in addition to the diffusion of the national CLTS guide. The municipality-wide open defecation approach was implemented in ten municipalities. Thanks to UNICEF direct support, a total of 362,380 additional people lives in 584 newly certified open defecation communities. In addition, an orientation note was developed on CLTS in emergencies with a focus on disabilities and vulnerabilities. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:22/01/2020

title.narrative: Number of schools with Menstrual Hygiene Management implemented in schools programmes as a result of UNICEF direct support and/or leveraged through national programmes.
